Also, one player got ahead with the number of cities and overall map dominance, and with the high cost of destroying cities, it didn't seem like a good option to start combat, so the 2 other players focused on simply building their own new cities. Arguably too long for what it is. The beginning is procedural, the middle you're primarily being buffeted by uneven calamities, and the last several hours half the table knows they've already lost.

The base mechanic of your population doubling and being forced to expand, of your population chits shifting between your stock and your treasury mirroring the rise and fall of cities, urban vs rural population etc, is all fantastic. The way population moves like amoeba, with porous borders, a chunk of thracians squeezed out into gall will breed like rabbits.

Nothing you do on the map matters on its own, its only good for its resource cards. That every single decision you make in this game, must be transmuted through the lens of a successful trade, severely undermines the map stakes. Being forced to trade over and over again and put on your pretty trading face and grin and make nice at people for 8 hours is exhausting. There's a trickle of treasure to spend directly or buy gold, but I wish you could accomplish more on your own. In every game my favorite moment is revealing myself as the evil emperor that the whole table has to try to stop. Though giving more individual agency would create more issues with how powerful going last in move order is.

The AST track should either be rebalanced on every player count and map, or it should be symmetric between civs. Player balancing can easily dominate any minor imbalances in start. Tech powers are not quite strong enough that an early lead is decisive, but the later differences in AST hurdles are huge.

Ships feel a little silly, they should maybe be increasingly more expensive to build a large fleet, so that you're incentivized to keep them around rather than constantly scrapping them to teleport them to where you need them for the meager cost of a coin.

I don't know where to begin on the calamities. They're not balanced for player count. They're not fun dramatic table moments, just misery. They're easily trackable which ruins trading. They arrive somewhat arbitrarily. They should maybe all be secret-backed and the decks shuffled. A late civil war can be game ending where most others can be shrugged off (there should be more civil war mitigation sprinkled into the early civics if it's going to be left as is). I managed to dump a Civil war on someone and it eliminated them from the game. It wasn't an interesting moment, it was just sad as I watched them kick themselves and deflate. I don't know how to fix this.

The base game is strong, I think it needs less complication and faster play, not more chrome, to fix it.

I love how smooth this plays, and how elegant combat works. I love the trading phase which keeps players engaged with each other even from across the table. I hate the length of the game. The game clicks along well enough until you hit this wall in the last 4th of the advancement track, where the requirement to proceed and advance the timer of the game becomes a massive amount of different tech cards. I would adore a more modern sped up version of this same system, but then, hasn't nearly every modern euro civ tried to live up to the promise of this game and fallen short?

I would have kept it, but honestly my tolerance for games of this length are just gone. I cap out at about 6 hours of time in a single game.
